Given a set <math display="inline">U</math> and <math display="inline">X \subseteq U</math>, the complement of <math display="inline">X</math> is:

<math display="block">\overline{X} \stackrel{\text{def}}{=} \left\{ x \in U: x \not\in X \right\}</math>

== Remark ==
* <math display="inline">\overline{X}</math> and <math display="inline">X</math> are disjoint, to see why, suppose we have <math display="inline">x \in \overline{X} \cap X</math> then <math display="inline">x \in X</math> and <math display="inline">x \not\in X</math> that's clearly a contradiction so there are no elements both in <math display="inline">X</math> and <math display="inline">\overline{X}</math> thus <math display="inline">X \cap \overline{X} = \varnothing</math>
